ExampleWords.AUni: make, build, construct, create, fabricate, fashion, form, generate, manufacture, prepare, produce, shape, bring into being,

Question.AUni: (2) What words refer to something that has been made?
(2) ما هي الكلمات التي تعني شيئا ما قد وقع صُنعه؟

ExampleWords.AUni: artifact, building, construction, manufactured goods, product, production

Question.AUni: (3) What words refer to a person who makes something?
(3) ما هي الكلمات التي تعني شخصا يصنع شيئا ما؟

ExampleWords.AUni: builder, maker, producer, manufacturer

Question.AUni: (4) What words describe something that was made?
(4) ما هي الكلمات التي تصف شيئا ما قد صُنِع؟

ExampleWords.AUni: man-made, hand-made, manufactured, artificial, synthetic

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words referring to someone changing something.

Question.AUni: (1) What words are used to refer to changing something?
(1) ما هي الكلمات التي تعني تغيير شيء ما؟

ExampleWords.AUni: change (v), change (n), revise, revision, revolutionize, revolution, reform, reformation, modify, modification, develop, development, make different, impact, process, transform,

Question.AUni: (2) What words refer to a person who changes something?
(2) ما هي الكلمات التي تعني شخصا يُغيِّر شيئا ما؟

ExampleWords.AUni: revolutionary, reformer, radical

Question.AUni: (3) What words describe something that can be changed?
(3) ما هي الكلمات التي تصف شيئا ما يُمكن تغييره؟

ExampleWords.AUni: changeable

Question.AUni: (4) What words describe a big change?
(4) ما هي الكلمات التي تصف تغييرا كبيرا؟

ExampleWords.AUni: big, major, sweeping, radical, fundamental, revolutionary, monumental,

Question.AUni: (5) What words describe a small change?
(5) ما هي الكلمات التي تصف تغييرا صغيرا؟

ExampleWords.AUni: small, slight, tiny, minute,

Question.AUni: (6) What words describe a quick change?
(6) ما هي الكلمات التي تصف تغييرا سريعا؟

ExampleWords.AUni: quick, fast, rapid,

Question.AUni: (7) What words describe a slow change?
(7) ما هي الكلمات التي تصف تغييرا بطيئا؟

ExampleWords.AUni: slow, gradual,

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words that indicate event propositions. Event propositions are similar in that they are normally expressed by a subject and a verb, possibly including an object, indirect object, or complement clause. However there are multiple ways in which a language can express an event, such as a passive construction, noun phrase, or subordinate clause. In addition each event type is different in its primary cases, and in the ways those cases are marked. Each event type has subtypes, such as intransitive, transitive, and bitransitive verbs. A great deal of research is needed in order to identify all the variations. Ultimately every verb must be investigated to determine how it behaves in each syntactic construction and how its case relations are marked. No two verbs are entirely alike.

Question.AUni: (1) What words indicate an event?
(1) ما هي الكلمات التي تُبرز وقوع حدث؟

ExampleWords.AUni: -ing, -'s...-ing, -ing...of, to,

AStr.Run: A bark<ing> dog (kept me awake last night).; The dog<'s> bark<ing> (woke me up).; The bark<ing> <of> a dog (woke me up).; (John told me) <to> wake him up at 6 a.m.; I want <to> do something.; He started do<ing> something.
Use this domain for general words referring to things.

Question.AUni: (1) What general words refer to a thing?
(1) ما هي الكلمات العامّة التي تعني شيئا؟

ExampleWords.AUni: thing, something, article, artifact, entity, item, object, wares,

Question.AUni: (2) What words refer to a group of things of different types?
(2) ما هي الكلمات التي تعني مجموعة من الأشياء من أنواع مُختلفة؟

ExampleWords.AUni: things, oddments, paraphernalia, stuff, odds and ends, bits and pieces, knick-knacks,

Question.AUni: (3) What words are used to refer to something when you can't remember what it is called?
(3) ما هي الكلمات التي تُستعمل لتُشير إلى شيء ما عندما لا تستطيع أن تتذكّر اسمه؟

ExampleWords.AUni: what's its name, thingy, thingamajig, whatchamacallit, whatsit, such and such

Question.AUni: (4) What words are used to end a list of things to indicate that there are more things in the list?
(4) ما هي الكلمات التي تُستعمل لإنهاء قائمة من الأشياء مع ابراز أنّه توجد أشياء أخرى في القائمة؟

ExampleWords.AUni: et cetera, etc., and what not, and so forth, and the like, and on and on, ... [ellipsis]

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words describing something that is physical--that you can touch and see, and for words describing something that is non-physical--that you cannot touch or see.

Question.AUni: (1) What words describe something that is physical?
(1) ما هي الكلمات التي تصف شيئا ما يكون ماديّا؟

ExampleWords.AUni: animal nature, biological, bodily, concrete, corporal, corporeal, earthly, earthy, fleshly, incarnate, inferior, matter, material, materialistic, mundane, natural, objective, physical, seen, sensible, sensual, tangible, temporal, unspiritual, worldly

AStr.Run: A ghost cannot take <physical> form.

Question.AUni: (2) What words refer to something that is physical?
(2) ما هي الكلمات التي تُشير إلى شيء ما يكون ماديّا؟

ExampleWords.AUni: substance, stuff, matter, material

Question.AUni: (3) What words describe something that is non-physical?
(3) ما هي الكلمات التي تصف شيئا ما يكون غير مادّيّ؟

ExampleWords.AUni: disembodied, extramundane, extrasensory, immaterial, impalpable, incorporeal, instinctive, intangible, intellectual, libidinal, life, mental, metaphysical, nonphysical, nonmaterial, numinous, otherworldly, preternatural, psychic, psychological, rational, reasoning, spiritual, spiritualist, subjective, supernatural, transcendent, transcendental, unbodied, unearthly, unseen, unworldly,

AStr.Run: Thoughts and ideas belong to the <spiritual> realm.

Question.AUni: (4) What words refer to something that is non-physical?
(4) ما هي الكلمات التي تُشير إلى شيء غير مادّيّ؟

ExampleWords.AUni: spirit

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words referring to a situation--a particular time and place, and the things that are true about it.

Question.AUni: (1) What words refer to the general situation that exists in a place?
(1) ما هي الكلمات التي تعني الوضعيّة العامّة التي تُوجد في مكان؟

ExampleWords.AUni: situation, things, conditions, state of affairs, set-up, context,

Question.AUni: (2) What words refer to a situation that affects what can happen or what people can do?
(2) ما هي الكلمات التي تصف حالة تُؤثِّر على الشّيء الذي يُمكن أن يحصل أو على ما يقدر النّاس على فعله؟

ExampleWords.AUni: situation, circumstances, environment, climate, conditions, the lay of the land, which way the wind blows, scenario,

Question.AUni: (3) What words refer to a situation that exists at some time during a larger event or process?
(3) ما هي الكلمات التي تعني وضعيّة توجد في فترة زمنيّة ما خلال حدث أكبر أو عمليّة أكبر؟

ExampleWords.AUni: situation, position, state of play,

Question.AUni: (4) What words refer to the true situation rather than the situation that people think exists?
(4) ما هي الكلمات التي تعني الوضعيّة الحقيقيّة وليس الوضعيّة التي يعتقد النّاس بأنّها توجد؟

ExampleWords.AUni: the picture, the score, what's going on,

Question.AUni: (5) What words refer to the situation a person is in?
(5) ما هي الكلمات التي تعني الوضعيّة التي يكون فيها شخص؟

ExampleWords.AUni: situation, circumstances, position, case, plight,

Question.AUni: (6) What words indicate that something must happen or cannot happen because of the situation?
(6) ما هي الكلمات التي تُبرز أنّ شيئا ما يجب أن يحدث أو أنّه لا يقدر أن يحدث نتيجة الوضعيّة؟

ExampleWords.AUni: under the circumstances, in the circumstances, given the circumstances, given the situation, as it is, as things stand, force of circumstances, the way things are,

AStr.Run: Use this domain for general adjectives that can replace or stand for a specific adjective.

Question.AUni: (1) What general words can replace an adjective?
(1) ما هي الكلمات العامّة التي يُمكن أن تُعوّضُ نعتا؟

ExampleWords.AUni: such, that kind of, that sort of,

AStr.Run: We all admire <such> a man. (a generous man); We all admire <that kind of> a man.; We all admire <that sort of> a man.

Question.AUni: (2) What question words ask for an adjective in the answer?
(2) ما هي الأدوات الاستفهاميّة التي تسأل عن إجابة فيها نعت؟

ExampleWords.AUni: what kind of, what sort of,

AStr.Run: <What kind of> a man is he? (a good man); <What sort of> man is he?

Question.AUni: (3) What question words ask for an ad-adjective in the answer?

ExampleWords.AUni: how,

AStr.Run: <How> big a box is it? (very big)
Use this domain for general adverbs that can replace or stand for other adverbs.

Question.AUni: (1) What general words can replace an adverb?
(1) ما هي الكلمات العامّة التي يُمكن أن تُعوّض ظرف الحال؟

ExampleWords.AUni: thus, thusly, so, how, like this, this way, in that way, in this manner

AStr.Run: We would like you to do it <thus>.; I'll show you <how> I want it.

This domain is for organization purposes and should not be used for any words. Use the domains in this section for words that belong to a particular part of speech. It is best not to use these domains, since they are based on grammar and not meaning. But if you have a small group of words that belong to a part of speech and you want to list them all, you can use these domains. You can also classify words in this section if you don't know what they mean yet.

Use this domain to list all adjectives. If there are many adjectives in your language, you should not try to list them all here. If you want to find all the adjectives, most dictionary programs can sort your dictionary by part of speech. However if your language only has a few adjectives, you can list them all in this domain. In the book, "Where Have All the Adjectives Gone?" R. M. W. Dixon [Dixon, R. M. W. 1982. Where have all the adjectives gone? Berlin: Mouton.] identifies seven universal semantic types that are often expressed by adjectives. They are: Age (new, young, old), Dimension (big, little, long, short, wide, narrow, thick, fat, thin), Value (good, bad, proper, perfect, excellent, fine, delicious, atrocious, poor), Color (black, white, red), Human propensity (jealous, happy, kind, clever, generous, cruel, rude, proud, wicked), Physical property (hard, soft, heavy, light, rough, smooth, hot, cold, sweet, sour), Speed (fast, slow). Words in the Human propensity class may be nouns. Words in the Physical property and Speed classes may be verbs.

Question.AUni: (1) What are the adjectives in your language?
(1) ما هي النّعوت في لغتك؟

ExampleWords.AUni: young, big, good, black, kind, hot, fast,

AStr.Run: Use this domain to list all adverbs. If there are many adverbs in your language, it is probably not worth the trouble to list them here. The Shoebox program (and other dictionary programs) can sort your dictionary by part of speech.

Question.AUni: (1) What adverbs are in your language?
(1) ما هي ظُروف الحال في لُغتك؟

ExampleWords.AUni: quickly

AStr.Run: Use this domain for the personal pronouns, including independent, subject, object, and possessive pronouns. It is best to collect all the pronouns in a chart. This way you are more certain of collecting them all and seeing how they are related to each other. A language may have more sets and more distinctions than English does, or it may have less. For instance some languages have a pronoun 'we' which includes the hearer, and another pronoun 'we' which excludes the hearer. Other languages have an indefinite pronoun that means something like the English word 'someone'. Many languages do not have the masculine (he), feminine (she), and neuter (it) distinctions that English has. It is necessary to determine the sets and functions of the pronouns for each language.

Question.AUni: (1) What general words refer to the class of pronouns?
(1) ما هي الكلمات العامّة التي تعني فئة الضّمائر؟

ExampleWords.AUni: pronoun

Question.AUni: (2) What pronouns refer to the speaker?
(2) ما هي الضّمائر التي تُشير إلى المتكلّم؟

ExampleWords.AUni: I, me, my, mine

Question.AUni: (3) What pronouns refer to the speaker and those associated with the speaker?
(3) ما هي الضّمائر التي تُشير إلى المتكلّم والأشخاص الذين لهم علاقة معه؟

ExampleWords.AUni: we, us, our, ours

Question.AUni: (4) What pronouns refer to the audience?
(4) ما هي الضّمائر التي تُشير إلى المستمعين؟

ExampleWords.AUni: you, your, yours

Question.AUni: (5) What pronouns refer to the people or things being spoken about?
(5) ما هي الضّمائر التي تُشير إلى النّاس أو الأشياء التي يُتكلّم بشأنه؟

ExampleWords.AUni: he, him, his, she, her, hers, it, its, they, them, their, theirs

Question.AUni: (6) What pronouns are used for the subject of a sentence?
(6) ما هي الضّمائر التي تُستعمل من أجل الفاعل في الجملة؟

ExampleWords.AUni: I, you, he, she, it, we, you, they

AStr.Run: <I> went to town.

Question.AUni: (7) What pronouns are used for the object of a sentence?
(7) ما هي الضّمائر التي تُستعمل من أجل المفعول به في الجملة؟

ExampleWords.AUni: me, you, him, her, it, us, you, them

AStr.Run: John hit <me>.

Question.AUni: (8) What pronouns are used in a possessive phrase?
(8) ما هي الضّمائر التي تُستعمل في جملة إمتلاكيّة؟

ExampleWords.AUni: my, your, his, her, its, our, your, their

AStr.Run: This is <my> house.

Question.AUni: (9) What pronouns are used in a possessive clause?
(9) ما هي الضّمائر التي تُستعمل في جملة امتلاكيّة؟

ExampleWords.AUni: mine, yours, his, hers, its, ours, yours, theirs

AStr.Run: That house is <mine>.

Question.AUni: (10) What pronouns are used to emphasize the people or things being spoken about, especially when you are emphasizing that one person does something and not someone else?
(10) ما هي الضّمائر التي تُستعمل لتُؤكّد على النّاس أو الأشياء التي يقع التّكلّم بشأنها خاصّة عندما تُؤكّد على أنّ شخصا يفعل شيئا وليس شخصا آخر؟

ExampleWords.AUni: as for me (I), as for you (you), as for him (he), as for us (we), as for them (they)

AStr.Run: He <himself> admits he is guilty.; I did it <myself> without any help.; You can do what you want. <As for me>, I'm not going.
Use this domain for pronouns that refer back to the subject of the sentence. These pronouns should be added to the chart of personal pronouns.

Question.AUni: (1) What pronouns express reflexive reference?
(1) ما هي الضّمائر التي تُعبّر عن مرجِع انعكاسي؟

ExampleWords.AUni: self, myself, yourself, himself, herself, itself, ourselves, yourselves, themselves, oneself

AStr.Run: I cut <myself>.

Question.AUni: (2) What pronouns express reciprocal reference?
(2) ما هي الضّمائر التي تُعبِّرُ عن مرجع تبادلي؟

ExampleWords.AUni: each other, one another

AStr.Run: They hit <each other>.; We should help <one another>.

Use this domain for pronouns that do not refer to a definite person or thing, but can refer to anyone or anything. Some languages will not have all the sets of pronouns described below. Add each set you find in your language to the pronoun chart.

Question.AUni: (1) What pronouns express indefinite reference of a person?
(1) ما هي الضّمائر التي تعبّر على شخص مبهم؟

ExampleWords.AUni: person, who, someone, anyone, everyone, no one, each one, whoever

Question.AUni: (2) What pronouns express indefinite reference of a thing?
(2) ما هي الضمائر التي تعبّر على شيء مبهم؟

ExampleWords.AUni: thing, what, something, anything, everything, nothing, each thing, whatever, whichever

Question.AUni: (3) What pronouns express indefinite reference of a time?
(3) ما هي الضّمائر التي تعبّر على وقت مبهم؟

ExampleWords.AUni: time, period, when, sometime, anytime, every time, never, at no time, each time, whenever, sometimes

Question.AUni: (4) What pronouns express indefinite reference of a place?
(4) ما هي الضّمائر التي تعبّر على مكان مبهم؟

ExampleWords.AUni: place, where, somewhere, anywhere, everywhere, nowhere, each place, wherever, which way

Question.AUni: (5) What pronouns express indefinite reference of a reason?
(5) ما هي الضّمائر التي تُعبّر على سبب مبهم؟

ExampleWords.AUni: reason, why, for what reason, for some reason, for any reason, for each and every reason, for no reason, why ever

Question.AUni: (6) What pronouns express indefinite reference of a manner?
(6) ما هي الضّمائر التي تُعبّر على كيفيّة مُبهمة؟

ExampleWords.AUni: manner, means, how, somehow, anyhow, every way, no way, each way, however

Question.AUni: (7) What pronouns express indefinite reference of an amount?
(7) ما هي الضّمائر التي تُعبّر على كميّة مُبهمة؟

ExampleWords.AUni: amount, how much, however many, however much, plenty

AStr.Run: Use this domain for pronouns used in relative clauses.

Question.AUni: (1) What pronouns are used in relative clauses?
(1) ما هي الضّمائر التي تُستعمل في الجمل الموصولة؟

ExampleWords.AUni: who, whom, that, which, why

AStr.Run: I'm looking for the man <who> killed John.; I found the coin <that> I lost.; That is the reason <why> I did it.
Use this domain for pronouns used in questions.

Question.AUni: (1) What pronouns are used in questions?
(1) ما هي الضّمائر التي تُستعمل في الأسئلة؟

ExampleWords.AUni: who, what, when, where, how, why

AStr.Run: <Who> is that?; <Where> did you go?; <How many> did you get?; <How often> will you go?; <Why> did you do that?
Use this domain for demonstrative pronouns.

Question.AUni: (1) What pronouns are used to indicate a particular referent?
(1) ما هي الضّمائر التي تُستعمل لتُبرز مشارا إليه معيّنا؟

ExampleWords.AUni: a, an, the, this, these, that, those, specific,

AStr.Run: <the> leader; <a> really old man; <this> new shirt; <these> tomatoes; <that> book; <those> flowers; I want <this>.; <That> is what I want.
Use this domain for words that indicate that someone does something himself, rather than through someone else.

Question.AUni: (1) What words are used to indicate that you do something yourself, rather than through someone else?
(1) ما هي الكلمات التي تُستعمل لتُبرز بأنّك تقوم بشيء بنفسك وليس من خلال شخص آخر؟

ExampleWords.AUni: personally, in person, direct

AStr.Run: You don't need to do anything. I will take care of it <personally>.; Instead of sending a representative, he is coming <in person>.; You can talk to him <direct>.

Question.AUni: (2) What words are used to indicate that you make something yourself rather than using a machine?
(2) ما هي الكلمات التي تُبرز بأنّك تصنع شيء بنفسك وليس عن طريق استعمال آلة؟

ExampleWords.AUni: by hand

AStr.Run: We made this book entirely <by hand>, using locally available materials.
Use this domain to list all prepositions and postpositions.

Question.AUni: (1) What prepositions are in your language?
(1) ما هي أدوات الجر الموجودة في لُغتك؟

ExampleWords.AUni: in, on, at, from, to, away, toward, about,

AStr.Run: Use this domain to list all conjunctions.

Question.AUni: (1) What conjunctions are in your language?
(1) ما هي كلمات الربط الموجودة في لغتك؟

ExampleWords.AUni: and, or, but,

Name.AUni: كلمات الربط بالنّسبة لجملة ليس بها فعل

AStr.Run: Use this domain to list all phrase level conjunctions--conjunctions that join two words within a phrase.

Question.AUni: (1) What conjunctions join two words within a phrase?
(1) ما هي كلمات الربط التي تربط كلمتين وسط جملة ليس بها فعل؟

ExampleWords.AUni: and, both...and, or, either...or, neither...nor, but,

AStr.Run: coming <and> going; me <and> you; men <and> women; <both> this <and> that; <either> good <or> bad; <neither> good <nor> bad; quickly <but> not carelessly

Name.AUni: الربط بالنسبة لجملة (غير كاملة) بها فعل

AStr.Run: Use this domain to list all clause level conjunctions--conjunctions that join two clauses.

Question.AUni: (1) What conjunctions join two clauses?
(1) ما هي أدوات العطف التي تربط جملتين غير كاملتين؟

ExampleWords.AUni: and, or, while, then, if, because,

AStr.Run: You come here <and> I'll go there.; You come here <or> I'll go there.; You come here <while> I go there.; You come here <then> I'll go there.; <If> you come here, I'll go there.
Use this domain to list all sentence level conjunctions--conjunctions that join two sentences.

Question.AUni: (1) What conjunctions join two sentences?
(1) ما هي أدوات العطف التي تربط جملتين؟

ExampleWords.AUni: then, so,

AStr.Run: I want you to come here. <Then> I'll go there.; You wanted to come here. <So> I decided to let you.
Use this domain to list all particles.

Question.AUni: (1) What particles are in your language?
(1) ما هي أدوات الجزم الموجودة في لُغتك؟

ExampleWords.AUni: He lives <just> across the street.

Name.AUni: الكلمات أو الحروف الزائدة التي يمكن من خلالها تحديد الوظيفة اللّغويّة للكلمة وسط الجملة

AStr.Run: Use this domain to list all classifiers.

Question.AUni: (1) What words indicate the class of something?
(1) ما هي الكلمات أو الحروف الزائدة التي تُبرز وظيفة شيء ما؟

ExampleWords.AUni: (Japanese) -hon (long objects), -mai (flat objects), -ban (order in a series), -nin (people), -fun (minutes), -dai (large vehicles)

Name.AUni: عبارات تُستعمل للتّعبير عن إحساس أو انفعال

AStr.Run: Use this domain to list all interjections.

Question.AUni: (1) What interjections are in your language?
(1) ما هي عبارات التّعجّب الموجودة في لُغتك؟

ExampleWords.AUni: Wow! Hold on! Good grief!

AStr.Run: Use this domain to list all idiophones. If there are many idiophones in your language, it is probably not worth the trouble to list them here. The Shoebox program (and other dictionary programs) can sort your dictionary by part of speech.

Question.AUni: (1) What idiophones are in your language?
(1) ما هيالحركات الصوتية الموجودة في لغتك؟

ExampleWords.AUni: knick-knack, flimflam

Name.AUni: الحروف الزّائدة في الكلمة هذا الجزء يجب أن يُنجزه عالِم لغة

AStr.Run: Use this domain to list all affixes that do not fit in any of the subdomains under it. This section should be filled out by a linguist.

Question.AUni: (1) What affixes are in your language?
(1) ما هي الحروف الزّائدة التي تكون موجودة في لغتك؟

ExampleWords.AUni: -s, -ed, -ing

AStr.Run: Use this domain to list all verb affixes.

Question.AUni: (1) What affixes can be joined to verbs?
(1) ما هي الحروف الزّائدة التي يُمكن أن تلتصق بالفعل؟

ExampleWords.AUni: -ing, -ed, -s

AStr.Run: Use this domain to list all noun affixes.

Question.AUni: (1) What affixes can be joined to nouns?
(1) ما هي الحروف الزائدة التي يمكن أن تلتصق بالإسم؟

ExampleWords.AUni: -s, -en

Name.AUni: الحروف الزائدة التي تغيّر وظيفة الكلمة

AStr.Run: Use this domain to list all derivational affixes. A derivational affix is joined to a root and changes it into a different word. Derivational affixes often change the root into a different part of speech. Adding a derivational affix usually changes the meaning of the root in a significant way.

Question.AUni: (1) What derivational affixes are there?
(1) ما هي الحروف الزّائدة التي تُضاف إلى الكلمات لتُغيِّر وظيفتها اللّغويّة؟

ExampleWords.AUni: un-, a-, self-, super-, -ment, -hood, -ous, -ly, -fy

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words that intensify an attribute.

Question.AUni: (1) What words intensify an attribute?
(1) ما هي الكلمات التي تُقوّي نعتا؟

ExampleWords.AUni: very, really, highly, deeply, real, so, mighty, one, quite, ever so, bloody, decidedly, too, proper, true, extremely, such

AStr.Run: <very> green; <too> dark; <really> fast; <real> good; <pretty> heavy

Question.AUni: (2) What words intensify an attribute to an extreme degree?
(2) ما هي الكلمات التي تُقوّي صفة نعت إلى درجة كبيرة؟

ExampleWords.AUni: extremely, terribly, dreadfully, incredibly, unbelievably, ridiculously, absurdly, remarkably, exceptionally, extraordinarily, terrifically, enormously, hugely, exceedingly,

Question.AUni: (3) What words indicate that an attribute is not intense?
(3) ما هي الكلمات التي تُبرز بأنّ نعتا ليس قويّا؟

ExampleWords.AUni: not very, hardly, barely, a little, fairly

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words that indicate a degree on a scale.

Question.AUni: (1) What words refer to the degree of something?
(1) ما هي الكلمات التي تعني درجة شيء ما؟

ExampleWords.AUni: degree, extent, level, thus

Question.AUni: (2) What words indicate a degree on a scale?
(2) ما هي الكلمات التي تُبرز درجة على مقياس ما؟

ExampleWords.AUni: high, low, greater, lesser, first, primary, secondary,

AStr.Run: Ambassador Stevenson is a very <high> level official.; <Low> priority tasks should be placed later in the list.; The musician gave a <first> rate performance.; Finding a suitable place to live was of <primary> importance.

Question.AUni: (3) What words refer to a marked extent?
(3) ما هي الكلمات التي تعني مدا ملحوظا؟

ExampleWords.AUni: up to, as much as, to the degree that

Question.AUni: (4) What words refer to a change in degree?
(4) ما هي الكلمات التي تعني تغيّرا في الدّرجة؟

ExampleWords.AUni: fluctuate, fluctuation, move, vary,

Question.AUni: (5) What words express a comparative degree?
(5) ما هي الكلمات التي تُعبّر عن درجة نسبيّة؟

ExampleWords.AUni: more, -er

AStr.Run: fast<er>

Question.AUni: (6) What words express a superlative degree?
(6) ما هي الكلمات التي تُعبّر عن درجة أرفع؟

ExampleWords.AUni: most, -est

AStr.Run: fast<est>
Use this domain for words referring to a large degree.

Question.AUni: (1) What words indicate a large degree?
(1) ما هي الكلمات التي تُبرز درجة كبيرة؟

ExampleWords.AUni: large, great, major, considerable, large scale, huge, enormous, immense, tremendous, high, advanced, rich,

Question.AUni: (2) What words refer to a large degree?
(2) ما هي الكلمات التي تُشير إلى درجة كبيرة؟

ExampleWords.AUni: size, magnitude,

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words referring to a small degree.

Question.AUni: (1) What words indicate a small degree?
(1) ما هي الكلمات التي تُبرز درجة صغيرة؟

ExampleWords.AUni: deficient, inappreciably, inconsequentially, insignificantly, lacking, lightly, limited, little, low, merely, moderately, negligibly, piddling, possible, puny, reasonably, relatively, slightly, somewhat, sparingly, temperately, trivial, trivially,

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words referring to a larger degree.

Question.AUni: (1) What words indicate that something is becoming larger in degree?
(1) ما هي الكلمات التي تُبرز بأنّ شيئا ما يُصبح أكبر درجة؟

ExampleWords.AUni: advance, double, explode, gain, grow, increase, jump, rise, rocket, soar, triple,

Question.AUni: (2) What words refer to the amount by which something became larger?
(2) ما هي الكلمات التي تعني الكميّة التي يُصبح بها شيء ما أكبر؟

ExampleWords.AUni: growth, explosion, hike, increase, rise,

Question.AUni: (3) What words refer to causing something to become larger in degree?
(3) ما هي الكلمات التي تُشير إلى جَعل شيء ما يُصبح أكبر درجة؟

ExampleWords.AUni: increase, raise, swell

Question.AUni: (4) What words indicate that something is larger than another thing in degree?
(4) ما هي الكلمات التي تُبرز بأنّ شيئا ما أكبر درجة من شيء آخر؟

ExampleWords.AUni: more than,

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words referring to a smaller degree.

Question.AUni: (1) What words indicate that something is becoming smaller in degree?
(1) ما هي الكلمات التي تُبرز بأنّ شيئا ما يُصبح أصغر درجة؟

ExampleWords.AUni: decline, decrease, diminish, drop, dwindle, fall, plummet, slide, tumble,

Question.AUni: (2) What words refer to the amount by which something became smaller?
(2) ما هي الكلمات التي تُشير إلى المقدار التي نَقُص من شيء ما حتّى يُصبح أصغر ؟

ExampleWords.AUni: decline (n), decrease, fall, reduction, tumble

Question.AUni: (3) What words refer to causing something to become smaller in degree?
(3) ما هي الكلمات التي تُشير إلى جَعل شيء ما يُصبح أصغر حجما؟

ExampleWords.AUni: decrease, lower, reduce,

Question.AUni: (4) What words indicate that something is smaller than another thing in degree?
(4) ما هي الكلمات التي تُبرز بأنّ شيئا ما أصغر درجة من شيء آخر؟

ExampleWords.AUni: less than, lower,

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words referring to a complete degree--when something is done, happens, is thought, is felt, etc completely and in every way.

Question.AUni: (1) What words indicate that something is done to a complete degree?
(1) ما هي الكلمات التي تبرز بأنّ شيئا ما يُنجز بدرجة كُلِّيّة؟

ExampleWords.AUni: completely, fully, totally, entirely, wholly, absolutely, utterly, positively, in every way, in every respect, in every sense, through and through, whole-heartedly, altogether, out-and-out, outright, perfect, perfectly, roundly, solid, solidly, thoroughly, unmitigated, unqualified, utter,

Question.AUni: (2) What general words refer to all of something's attributes or manners?
(2) ما هي الكلمات العامّة التي تُشير إلى كل ميزات أو أسلوب شيء ما؟

ExampleWords.AUni: completely, in every way,

Question.AUni: (3) What words describe something that is done completely?
(3) ما هي الكلمات التي تصف شيئا ما يُنجزُ كلّيّا؟

ExampleWords.AUni: complete, thorough, full, comprehensive, exhaustive, entire,

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words referring to a complete degree--when something is done, happens, is thought, is felt, etc completely and in every way.

Question.AUni: (1) What words indicate that something is done partly?
(1) ما هي الكلمات التي تُبرز بأنّ شيئا ما يُنجز جُزئيّا؟

ExampleWords.AUni: partly, partially, to some extent, to a certain extent, to a degree, to some degree, up to a point, in part, sort of,

Question.AUni: (2) What words indicate that something is done one part at a time?
(2) ما هي الكلمات التي تُبرز بأنّ شيئا ما يُنجَز كلّ جزء منها على مرحلة زمنيّة تُخصّص له؟

ExampleWords.AUni: gradually, in stages, step by step, one step at a time, in increments, incrementally, piecemeal, by degrees, little by little,

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words indicating intensity of an action.

Question.AUni: (1) What words are used to indicate that something is being done intensely?
(1) ما هي الكلمات التي تُستعمل لتُبرز بأنّ شيئا ما قد أُنجِز بشكل مكثّف؟

ExampleWords.AUni: intense, intensely, extensively

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words that modify an attribute.

Question.AUni: (1) What words modify an attribute?
(1) ما هي الكلمات التي تنعتُ؟

ExampleWords.AUni: fairly, sort of, quite,

AStr.Run: <light> blue, <dark> red, <dull> gray, <faded> colors

Name.AUni: المركّبات الدلالية في اللّغة والتي لها علاقة بالأفعال

AStr.Run: Use this section for verbal auxiliaries, affixes, adverbs, and particles that modify verbs.
Use this section for verbal auxiliaries, affixes, adverbs, and particles that indicate tense and aspect.

Name.AUni: الإطار الزماني التّعاريف التالية قد أخِذت من بيبي، جُوان، ريفري باركين ووليام باكليوكا. 1994. كتاب''تطوّر قواعد اللّغة''.شيكاغو و لندن : جامعة شيكاغو براس.

AStr.Run: Use this domain for verbal auxiliaries, affixes, adverbs, and particles that indicate tense (also known as temporal deixis)--the time of a situation (event, activity, or state) in relation to a reference point, which is usually the time of utterance. The following definitions are taken from Bybee, Joan, Revere Perkins, and William Pagliuca. 1994. The evolution of grammar. Chicago and London: University of Chicago Press.

Question.AUni: (1) present: the situation occurs simultaneously with the moment of speech.
(1) زّمن الحاضر: الوضعيّة تحدث في نفس وقت الخطاب .
(2) past: the situation occurred before the moment of speech.
(2) زمن الماضي: الوضعيّة حصلت قبل وقت الخطاب.
(3) future: the situation takes place after the moment of speech; the speaker predicts that the situation in the proposition will hold.
(3) زمن المستقبل: الوضعيّة تحصل بعد وقت الخطاب، المتكلّم يتوقّع بأن الوضعية سوف تحصل في المستقبل.
(4) crastinal: tomorrow.
(4) كرستناس:غدا.
(5) hesternal: yesterday.
(5) رسترنال: البارحة
(6) hodiernal: today, normally with past.
(6) ورديارنال: اليوم، وعادة مع الماضي.
(7) pre-hodiernal: before today.
(7) ري أوديارنال: قبل اليوم.
(8) post-crastinal: after tomorrow.
(8) بوست كراستنال: بعد غد.
(9) ancient past: used for narrating events in ancient or mythical time.
(9) الماضي البعيد: يُستعمل لسرد أحداث وقعت في الماضي البعيد أو الماضي الأسطوري.
(10) remote: combines with other tense labels to indicate a situation occurring temporally distant from the moment of speech.
(10) البعيد: يجمع بين أوقات أخرى وذلك لإبراز وضعيّة تحصل في وقت زماني بعيد عن وقت الخطاب.
(11) immediate: a meaning label that may be combined with other tense labels to indicate a situation not simultaneous with the moment of speech, but very close to it.
(11) فوري: وقت يمكن أن يُدمَج مع أوقات أخرى وذلك لإبراز وضعيّة لا تحصل في نفس الوقت مع وقت الخطاب، ولكنّها تحصل في وقت قريب جدّا من وقت الخطاب.
(12) immediate future: what is about to occur.
(12) المستقبل الفوري: يحصل المستقبل الفوري مباشرة بعد وقت الخطاب
(13) immediate past: occurring immediately before the moment of speech. Also called the Recent Past. Do not use this label if there is any sense of current relevance--use anterior for that.
(13) لماضي المباشر: يحصل مباشرة قبل وقت الخطاب، ويسمّى كذلك بالماضي الحديث. لا تستعمل هذا الوقت إن كان هناك أيّ معنى من معاني التأثير على الوقت الحاضر بل استعمل الماضي من أجل ذلك.
(14) Immediate may also be combined with anterior or imperative.
(14) الوقت المباشر يمكن أن يكون ممزوجا مع الوقت الماضي أو الأمر.
(15) expected future: the situation is to occur in the near future; what is scheduled to happen.
(15) المستقبل المُنتَظَر: تحصل الوضعيّة في المستقبل القريب، وهذا الشيء قد عُيِّن حدوثه مسبقا.
(16) narrative time: the use of a form with no other past uses for reporting a past narrative.
(16) الوقت السّردي: إعتماد نوع من أنواع الوقت الزّمني من دون استعمال أيّ أوقات أخرى للماضي من أجل الاخبار بسرد في الماضي.

(17) gnomic present: the situation described in the proposition is generic; the predicate has held, holds, and will hold for the class of entities named by the subject, such as 'Elephants have trunks'.
(17) الحاضر الحيادي: الوضعيّة الموصوفة في الجملة عامّة. المسند إليه قد حصل ، وهو يحصل، وسيحصل بالنسبة لمجموعة من الأشياء التي قيلت بالنسبة للفاعل ، مثال:''يملك الفيلة خراطيم.''
(18) What general words refer to the tense of an event?
(18) ما هي الكلمات العامّة التي تعني الوقت الذي يحصل فيه حدث؟

ExampleWords.AUni: tense, time

Question.AUni: (19) What words are used to indicate the present tense?
(19) ما هي الكلمات التي تُستعمل لتُبرز زمن الحاضر؟

ExampleWords.AUni: (no words or affixes in English)

Question.AUni: (20) What words are used to indicate the past tense?
(20) ما هي الكلمات التي تُستعمل لتُبرز وقت الماضي؟

ExampleWords.AUni: -ed, (in English vowel replacement is also used to indicate past tense, e.g. run, ran)

Question.AUni: (21) What words are used to indicate the future tense?
(21) ما هي الكلمات التي تُستعمل لتُبرز وقت المستقبل؟

ExampleWords.AUni: will, going to

AStr.Run: Use this section for verbal auxiliaries, affixes, adverbs, and particles that indicate aspects of dynamic verbs. Aspects describe the temporal contours of a situation. They may be combined with any of the tenses, either in the same morpheme or in combinations of morphemes. The following definitions are taken from Bybee, Joan, Revere Perkins, and William Pagliuca. 1994. The evolution of grammar. Chicago and London: University of Chicago Press.

Question.AUni: (1) habitual: the situation is customary or usual, repeated on different occasion over a period of time. English 'used to' is past habitual; English 'Nancy sings' is present habitual.
(1) الإعتيادي: الوضعيّة مألوفة أو معتادة وهي تتكرّر في مناسبات مختلفة وهي وضعيّة تحصل على طول فترة من الزّمن.

(2) continuous: a single situation is viewed as in progress, as maintained over a period of time; also called "durative." The English "Progressive" is a continuous restricted to dynamic words. English 'I am reading; *I am knowing the number'.
(2) المتواصل: وضعيّة يُرى بأنّها في تطوّر ويكون ذلك التطوّر دائما وعلى فترة متواصلة من الزّمن، ويسمّى كذلك '' الاستمراري''
(3) continuative: keep on doing what is being done. Restricted to dynamic words.
(3) لمتواصل (نزع ثاني) : مواصلة القيام بالشّيء الذي يقع القيام به. يستعمل هذا الوقت فقط مع الكلمات المتحرّكة.

(4) progressive: the action takes place simultaneously with the moment of reference, 'to be in the process of...'. This is more restricted than the English Progressive, which may be used for events that are not actually in progress at reference time: 'I am writing a book' may be used even if the speaker is not at that moment writing.

(4) التّصاعدي: يحصل الفعل في نفس وقت التكلّم بشأنه (أي '' في تطوّر ") ويكون هذا الوقت محدود الاستعمال مقارنة بالتّصاعدي الانكليزي التي يُمكن استعماله مع أحداث ليست تصاعديّة في وقت الاشارة إليها في حقيقة الأمر: مثال :"I am writing a book" يمكن أن يُقال هذا المثال حتّى إن كان المتكلّم لا يكتب في الوقت الذي يتكلّم فيه.
(5) excessive duration: action is extended over a long period of time, longer than normal for that action.
(5) المدّة المُفرطة: يمتدّ الفعل على فترة زمنيّة طويلة أطول من الفترة العاديّة التي عادة ما تحصل بالنّسبة لما يقتضيه ذلك الفعل.
(6) limited duration: action performed for a relatively short or bounded period of time.
(6) المدّة المحدودة: فعل يُنجز في فترة قصيرة نسبيّا أو فترة محدودة من الزّمن.
(7) iterative: the action is repeated on one occasion; usually restricted to dynamic words, often further restricted to semelfactive words.
(7) التكراري مرّة واحدة: يُعاد الفعل في مناسبة واحدة ،ويحصل التكراري فقط مع الكلمات المتحرّكة
(8) frequentative: action occurs frequently, not necessarily habitually, nor necessarily on one occasion, as is the iterative.
(8) التّكراري: يحصل الفعل بصفة متكرّرة وليس بالضّرورة بصفة إعتياديّة وليس بالضّرورة مرّة واحدة مثلما يحصل مع ''التكراري مرّة واحدة''.
(9) imperfective: the situation is viewed as unbounded in the sense that it is habitual, continuous, progressive, or iterative.
(9) الغير مُكتمل: الوضعيّة تظهَرُ بأنّها غير محدودة بمعنى أنّها مُعتادة أو متواصلة أو تصاعديّة، أو تكراريّة لمرّة واحدة.
(10) perfective: the situation is viewed as bounded temporally. It cannot be simultaneous with the moment of speech; in the non-past it is sometimes interpreted as future.
(10) المكتمل:الوضعيّة تظهر محدودة زمنيّا. لا يمكن للوضعيّة أن تحصل في نفس الوقت مع الخطاب. كما أنّ المكتمل يُمكن بأن يُفهم بأنّه المستقبل عندما يُستعمل في الوقت الذي لا يُعبِّر عن الماضي.
(11) completive: to do something thoroughly and to completion, e.g. 'to shoot someone dead, to eat up'.
(11) المنتهي: القيام بشيء من بدايته إلى آخره وذلك إلى حدِّ النّهاية. مثال: ''إطلاق النّار عل شخص حتّى يُترك ميّتا''. مثال: ''إلتهام كلّ شيء''.
(12) inceptive: the action or event begins. We are distinguishing this from the beginning of a state.
(12) إستهلالي: يكون الفعل أو الحدث في بدايته. نُميِّزُ ذلك مقارنة ببداية حالة.
(13) delimited: action is performed only a little.
(13) محدود: يكون الفعل قد أنجِزَ قليلا.
(14) The preceding terms or "Aspects" are not usually relevant to stative words.
(14) الكلمات السّابقة أو ''الميزات'' عادة ما تكون ليست ذات صلة بالكلمات الخبريّة.
(15) What general words refer to an aspect of an event?
(15) ما هي الكلمات العامّة التي تعني ميزة حدث؟

ExampleWords.AUni: aspect

Question.AUni: (16) What words are used to indicate that something has begun?
(16) ما هي الكلمات التي تُستعمل لتُبرِز بأنّ شيئا ما قد بدأ؟

ExampleWords.AUni: begin, start, commence, beginning, the start, commencement, initiate, to institute, inception

Question.AUni: (17) What do people say when they want someone else to start?
(17) ما الذي يقوله النّاس عندما يرغبون بشخص آخر بأن يبدأ.

ExampleWords.AUni: go, dig in, have at it, let's go, let's do it, move it, let's get going, "on your marks, get set, go", "ready, set, go"

Question.AUni: (18) What is a person called who starts something?
(18) ماذا نُسمّي شخصا يبدأ في شيء ما؟

ExampleWords.AUni: initiator, founder, originator, starter

Question.AUni: (19) What words are used to indicate that someone is attempting to do something?
(19) ما هي الكلمات التي تُستعمل لتُبرز بأنّ شخصا ما بصدد محاولة القيام بشيء ما؟

ExampleWords.AUni: try, attempt

Question.AUni: (20) What words are used to indicate that something is being done quickly?
(20) ما هي الكلمات التي تُستعمل لتُبرز بأنّ شيئا ما يُنجَزُ بسرعة؟

ExampleWords.AUni: quick, quickly, rapidly

Question.AUni: (21) What words are used to indicate that something happened suddenly?
(21) ما هي الكلمات التي تُستعمل لتُبرز بأنّ شيئا ما حصل بصفة فجئيّة؟

ExampleWords.AUni: sudden, suddenly, suddenness, immediate

Question.AUni: (22) What words are used to indicate something is continuing?
(22) ما هي الكلمات التي تُستعمل لتُبرز بأنّ شيئا ما مُتواصل الحصول؟

ExampleWords.AUni: continue, continuous, keep on

Question.AUni: (23) What words are used to indicate that something has been completed?
(23) ما هي الكلمات التي تُستعمل لتُبرز بأنّ شيئا ما قد تمَّ؟

ExampleWords.AUni: complete, finish, succeed

AStr.Run: Use this section for verbal auxiliaries, affixes, adverbs, and particles that indicate aspects of stative verbs. Aspects describe the temporal contours of a situation. They may be combined with any of the tenses, either in the same morpheme or in combinations of morphemes. The following definitions are taken from Bybee, Joan, Revere Perkins, and William Pagliuca. 1994. The evolution of grammar. Chicago and London: University of Chicago Press.

Question.AUni: (1) state exists: the state is begun before reference time and continues after reference time.
(1) الحالة موجودة: تبدأ الحالة قبل الوقت المُشار إليه وهي تتواصل بعد الوقت المُشار إليه.

ExampleWords.AUni: is,

Question.AUni: (2) state commences: beginning of a state of "becoming." Often called Inceptive or Inchoative. If there is a morpheme specifically for this meaning, it is usually derivational and restricted to stative words. However, it is also possible for "Perfects" or "Perfectives" to have this as their use with stative words.

(2) لحالة تبدأ: بداية ''تحوّل الشّيء''. عادة ما تُسمّى الإستهلاليّة ، وإن كان هناك لفظة مُخصّصة من أجل هذا المعنى فإنّها عادة ما تكون مشتقّة من عبارات تضفي تغيير على الكلمات و عادة ما تكون مقتصرة على هذه العبارات. كما أنّه من الممكن'' للمكتمل'' أو (''المكتملين'') أن يكون له هذا الإستعمال عند استعماله مع الكلمات الخبريّة.

ExampleWords.AUni: becoming,

Question.AUni: (3) state ends: state existed in the past, but no longer exists. Also a possible meaning of "Perfects" or "Perfectives" in combination with stative words.
(3) لحالة التي انتهت:حالة وُجِدت في الماضي ولكنّها لم تعُد موجودة. كما يوجد معنى للكامل(أو المكتمل) عند المزج مع الكلمات الخبريّة.

ExampleWords.AUni: no longer,

Question.AUni: (4) state continues: state is continuing a reference time.
(4) لحالة تتواصل: الحالة تواصل في وقت قد أشِير إليه.

ExampleWords.AUni: still,

Question.AUni: (5) state changes: (self-explanatory).
(5) لحالة تتغيّر: (تُفسَّر بنفسها)

ExampleWords.AUni: turn,

AStr.Run: Use this section for verbal auxiliaries, affixes, adverbs, and particles that indicate relational tenses. Relational tenses describe situations where the reference time is not the same as the moment of speech. They may be combined with any of the tenses, either in the same morpheme or in combinations of morphemes. The following definitions are taken from Bybee, Joan, Revere Perkins, and William Pagliuca. 1994. The evolution of grammar. Chicago and London: University of Chicago Press.

Question.AUni: (1) resulting state (resultative): action in the past produces a state that persists into the present.
(1) لحالة النّاتجة: حالة في الماضي تُنتِج حالة مستمرّة في الوقت الحاضر.

ExampleWords.AUni: be... -en,

Question.AUni: (2) anterior continuing: past action continues into the present: 'I have waited over an hour' ( = and I'm still waiting).

(2) لحالة السّابقة المتواصلة:حالة في الماضي تتواصل في الحاضر. ''لقد انتظرت لمدّة ساعة'' (ولازلت أنتظر) \qun (3) لحالة السّابقة: الوضعيّة تحصل قبل وقت قد أشِير إليه وهي وضعيّة مُتعلّقة بحالة حدثت في وقت قد أشِير إليه. هذه الحالة مُختلفة عن الماضي (العادي) أو عن الكامل أين يتقرّر حصول الوضعيّة من أجل ذاتها وعندما تكون الوضعيّة مستقلّة من أيّة علاقة لها مع أيّة وضعيّة أخرى.

ExampleWords.AUni: have been... -ing,

Question.AUni: (3) anterior: the situation occurs prior to reference time, and is relevant to the situation at reference time. This is different from a simple past or perfective, where the situation is reported for its own sake and independent of its relevance to any other situation.
(3) لصّيغة التي تُشير إلى وضعيّة تكون سابقة لوقت سابق تمّت الإشارة إليه والتي تكون ذات صلة بوقت سابق سوف تُعطى إسمين فيهما معنى الماضي ومعنى السّابق.

ExampleWords.AUni: have... -en,

Question.AUni: (4) A form that signals a situation that is prior to and relevant to a past reference time will be coded with two meaning labels, past and anterior.

ExampleWords.AUni: had... -en,

Name.AUni: الصّيغ التي تجري تحت تأثير الفاعل

AStr.Run: Use this section for verbal auxiliaries, affixes, adverbs, and particles that indicate agent-oriented modalities. Agent-oriented modalities describe internal or external conditions on a willful agent with respect to the completion of the predicate situation. They may be combined with any of the tenses, either in the same morpheme or in combinations of morphemes. The following definitions are taken from Bybee, Joan, Revere Perkins, and William Pagliuca. 1994. The evolution of grammar. Chicago and London: University of Chicago Press.

Question.AUni: (1) ability: the agent of the verb has the mental or physical ability to complete the action of the main verb.
(1) لقدرة: الفاعل وراء الفعل عنده القدرة العقليّة أو البدنيّة لإتمام الفعل الأساسي.
(2) ability, mental: English: 'Melissa can speak Dutch'.
(2) لقدرة العقليّة. مثال: "ماليسا يمكن أن تتعلّم اللّغة الهولنديّة’’

ExampleWords.AUni: can,

Question.AUni: (3) ability, physical: English: 'Hortense can swim the English Channel'.
(3) لقدرة البدنية. مثال:"هرتنس يمكنه أن يسبح عبر قناة الانكليز''

ExampleWords.AUni: can,

Question.AUni: (4) attempt: the agent attempts to complete the action specified by the predicate. Note: this has a sense of incompleteness, and I have seen authors call this "Incomplete" and gloss the examples with 'try'.
(4) حاولة:يُحاول الفاعل إتمام الفعل الذي وقع تحديده. ملاحظة: هذا الشّيء فيه معنى عدم الاكتمال، وقد سمّاه بعض الكُتّاب ''الغير كامل'' واعتمدوا الأمثلة التي تحتوي على فعل '' يحاول''.

ExampleWords.AUni: try to, attempt to,

Question.AUni: (5) desire: the agent of the verb desires or wants to complete the action of the verb.
(5) رغب: الفاعل يرغب أو يريد إكمال القيام بأداء الفعل.

ExampleWords.AUni: want to, would like to,

Question.AUni: (6) obligation: the agent is obliged to perform the action of the verb.
(6) لضّرورة: الفاعل مجبور على إنجاز الفعل.
(7) obligation, strong: it is absolutely incumbent upon the agent to complete the action of the main verb: 'I have to mail this letter today'.
(7) لضّرورة القويّة: من الواجب المطلق على الفاعل بأن يتمّم الفعل الأساسي: ''يجي عليّ أن أُرسل الرّسالة اليوم.''

ExampleWords.AUni: have to, must,

Question.AUni: (8) obligation, weak: it is recommended that the agent complete the action of the main verb: 'Harry ought to get a haircut before meeting Sue's mother'.
(8) لضّرورة الضّعيفة: من المستحسن أن يقوم الفاعل بإتمام الفعل الأساسي: '' على هاري أن يحلق شعره قبل أن يلتقي بأمِّ سو.''

ExampleWords.AUni: ought to, should,

Question.AUni: (9) permission: the agent is allowed to complete the action of the main verb: 'The students may check books out for two weeks'.
(9) ذنٌ: قد أذِن للفاعل بأن يُتمّ القيام بالفعل الأساسي: ''يمكن للتّلاميذ أن يستعيروا الكتب لمدّة أسبوعين.''

ExampleWords.AUni: may,

Question.AUni: (10) root possibility: it is possible for the agent to carry out the action of the main verb; i.e. s/he is able and external conditions allow it: 'You can get that kind of paper at Ulbrich's'.
(10) مكانيّة جذريّة: من الممكن للفاعل بأن يُنفّذ الفعل الأساسي في الجملة. الفاعل قادر على ذلك كما أنّ الأوضاع الخارجيّة تسمح بذلك. مثال:'' يُمكنك التّحصّل على ذلك النّوع من الورق من عند أولبريك."

ExampleWords.AUni: can,

Question.AUni: (11) intention: the agent intends to carry out the action of the main verb: 'Sam's gonna take Sanskrit next semester'.
(11) لنيّة: ينوي الفاعل تنفيذ الفعل الأساسي: ''سوف يقوم سام بدراسة سانسكرت خلال النّصف الثاني من السّنة.''

ExampleWords.AUni: gonna, going to, intend to,

Question.AUni: (12) andative: agent moves away from the deictic center in order to do something, literally 'be going to do something'. Of course such forms are often related to the verb 'to go' and also may have uses of intention and future.

(12) التحرّك والإبتعاد :الفاعل يتحرّك بعيدا عن مركز الاشارة وذلك بهدف القيام بشيء ما، وبطبيعة الحال فإنّ مثل هذه الصّيغ عادة ما تكون مرتبطة بالفعل 'ذهب' ويُمكن أن تعتمد على تأثير النيّة ويمكن أن تعتمد كذلك على وقت المستقبل.

ExampleWords.AUni: go to,

Question.AUni: (13) venitive: the agent moves toward the deictic center in order to do something, literally 'be coming to do something'. This may be related to the verb 'to come' and may have future uses as well.
(13) التّحرّك والإقتراب: الفاعل يتحرّك تجاه مركز الإشارة وذلك بهدف القيام بشيء ما، و يمكن أن تكون هذه الصّيغة مرتبطة بالفعل 'أقدم' ويمكن أن تكون عندها إستعمالات لوقت المستقبل.

ExampleWords.AUni: come to,

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words indicating that someone can do something.

Question.AUni: (1) What words indicate that someone is able to do something?
(1) ما هي الكلمات التي تعني أنّ شخصا ما يستطيع القيام بشيء ما؟

ExampleWords.AUni: can, know how to, be able to, have the ability to, capable,

AStr.Run: John <can> drive a car.; John <knows how> to drive a car.

Question.AUni: (2) What words refer to the ability of someone to do something?
(2) ما هي الكلمات التي تعني قدرة شخص ما على القيام بشيء ما؟

ExampleWords.AUni: ability, capability, prowess,

Question.AUni: (3) What words indicate that someone is not able to do something?
(3) ما هي الكلمات التي تعني بأنّ شخصا ما غير قادر على القيام بشيء ما؟

ExampleWords.AUni: inability, unable, incapable,

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words related to being incapable of doing something.

Question.AUni: (1) What words describe a person's inability to do a job?
(1) ما هي الكلمات التي تصف عدم قدرة شخص ما على القيام بعمل؟

ExampleWords.AUni: can't do something, not be able to do something, cannot, be incapable of, not be capable of, be unable to do something, someone's inability to do something, incompetent, unqualified, unfitted, untrained, not be equipped, be ill-equipped, powerless,

Question.AUni: (2) What words refer to a person's inability to do a job?
(2) ما هي الكلمات التي تُشير إلى عدم قدرة شخص ما على القيام بعمل؟

ExampleWords.AUni: incapacity, incompetence, inability, deficiency, lack of training

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words that a speaker uses to indicate that he thinks something must happen.

Question.AUni: (1) What words indicate that something is necessary?
(1) ما هي الكلمات التي تعني بأنّ شيئا ما ضروريّ؟

ExampleWords.AUni: must, need to, have to, have got to

Question.AUni: (2) What words describe something that is necessary?
(2) ما هي الكلمات التي تصف شيئا ما يكون ضروريّا؟

ExampleWords.AUni: necessary, compulsory, essential, imperative, indispensable, inevitable, mandatory, obligatory, required, unavoidable, urgent, vital,

Question.AUni: (3) What words refer to something that is necessary?
(3) ما هي الكلمات التي تُشير إلى أنّ شيئا ما ضروري؟

ExampleWords.AUni: necessity, need, obligation, prerequisite, requirement,

Question.AUni: (4) What words describe something that is not necessary?
(4) ما هي الكلمات التي تصف شيئا ما غير ضروري؟

ExampleWords.AUni: unnecessary, extraneous, incidental, inessential, needless, nonessential, uncalled-for, unessential, unnecessary, unneeded,

AStr.Run: Use this section for verbal auxiliaries, affixes, adverbs, and particles that indicate moods.

Use this section for verbal auxiliaries, affixes, adverbs, and particles that indicate imperatives. The following definitions are taken from Bybee, Joan, Revere Perkins, and William Pagliuca. 1994. The evolution of grammar. Chicago and London: University of Chicago Press. Use this domain for words and affixes that a speaker uses to indicate that he is making a command. English has no command word. Some languages change the form of the verb by adding an affix. Some languages have special verbs that are only or normally used as commands. Those verbs could be classified here.

Question.AUni: (1) imperative: the verb form used for direct commands in the 2nd person. If there are also 1st and 3rd person forms, the meaning can still be that of imperative, with the 1st and 3rd persons being interpreted as 'Let us, let him...', etc.

(1) صيغة الأمر: يُستعمل الفعل من أجل الأوامر المباشرة مع المخاطَب ،وإن كان هناك ضمير متكلّم المتكلم أو الغائب فإنّ المعني يمكن أن يكون صيغة الأمر ويكون المتكلم و الغائب قد فُسِّر بمعناه ''دعونا، دعه...''، إلخ.
(2) optative: the proposition represents the speaker's will. Translated into English as 'May you prosper', 'May we all meet again.' with counterfactual: 'If only he had...', etc.
(2) صيغة التّمنّي: تُمثّل الجملة رغبة المتكلّم.
(3) hortative: the speaker is encouraging or inciting someone to action.
(3) صيغة التّشجيع: المتكلّم يُشجّع أو يحرّض شخصا ما على الفعل.
(4) prohibitive: the mood for expressing negative commands. The English is 'Don't'.
(4) صيغة التّحريم: صيغة أمر للتّعبير عن النفي.
(5) admonitive: the command constitutes a warning: 'you had better not...'.
(5) صيغة تحذير:هذا الأمر يُشكّل تحذيرا: ''من الأفضل لك عدم القيام بِه''.
(6) Meanings co-occurring with imperative:
(6) عاني تحدث في نفس الوقت مع صيغة الأمر:
(7) polite: a mild or polite form of command.
(7) هذّب: شكل من أشكال الأمر المهذّب أو المعتدل.
(8) delayed: the action of the command is to be carried out in the future rather than immediately.
(8) ؤجّل: القيام بالأمر سوف يحصل في المستقبل عوضا أن يحصل في الحال.
(9) immediate: the action of the command is to be carried out immediately.
(9) لفوري:القيام بالأمر سوف يحصل مباشرة.
(10) strong: (self-explanatory).
(10) وي(يُفسّر نفسه)
(11) What words indicate that the sentence is a command?
(11) ما هي الكلمات التي تُشير إلى أنّ الجملة أمر؟

ExampleWords.AUni: (none in English)

Question.AUni: (12) What affixes indicate that the sentence is a command?
(12) ما هي الحروف المزيدة التي تُبرز بأنّ الجملة أمر؟

ExampleWords.AUni: (none in English), (in many Bantu languages) -e 'a verbal suffix indicating that the sentence is a command'

Question.AUni: (13) What words are only used in the imperative?
(13) ما هي الكلمات التي تُستعمل في صيغة الأمر فقط؟

ExampleWords.AUni: whoa (stop)

AStr.Run: Use this domain for ways of saying that someone should do something. If I say someone should do something, I think it is good that he does it.

Question.AUni: (1) What words indicate that the speaker is encouraging or inciting someone to action.
(1) ما هي الكلمات التي تُبرز بأنّ المتكلّم بصدد تشجيع أو تحفيز شخص ما على القيام بعمل؟

ExampleWords.AUni: urge, request, let, why don't, please

AStr.Run: I <urge> you to help.; I <request> that you help.; <Let> us all do our part.; <Why don't> you do something to help?; <Please> do something to help.

Question.AUni: (2) What words indicate that something should be done?
(2) ما هي الكلمات التي تُبرز بأنّ شيئا ما يجب إنجازه؟

ExampleWords.AUni: should, ought to, be responsible for, be duty bound,

AStr.Run: We <should> do something to help.; We <ought to> do something to help.; <Should>n't we do something to help?; This building <should> be torn down.

Question.AUni: (3) What words indicate that something should not be done?
(3) ما هي الكلمات التي تُبرز بأنّ شيئا ما لا يجب أن يُنجز؟

ExampleWords.AUni: should not, ought not to, caution

AStr.Run: We <should not> do anything to hinder them.; We <ought not to> do anything that might harm them.; I <caution> you not to interfere.

Question.AUni: (4) What words refer to something a person should do?
(4) ما هي الكلمات التي تُشير إلى شيء ما يجب على شخص ما أن يُنجزه؟

ExampleWords.AUni: duty, responsibility, obligation, onus, requirement,

Question.AUni: (5) What words describe the person who should do something?
(5) ما هي الكلمات التي تصف الشّخص الذي يجب أن يقوم بشيء ما؟

ExampleWords.AUni: responsible,

Question.AUni: (6) What words describe someone who does what he should?
(6) ما هي الكلمات التي تصف شخصا ما يقوم بما يتوجّب عليه فعله؟

ExampleWords.AUni: dutiful, responsible

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words that a speaker uses to indicate that he is asking a question. English has no question word, but other languages such as Japanese do.

Question.AUni: (1) What words indicate that the sentence is a question?
(1) ما هي الكلمات التي تُبرز بأنّ الجملة سُؤال؟

ExampleWords.AUni: (Japanese) ka? 'a particle coming at the end of a sentence to indicate that it is a question'

Question.AUni: (2) English has an interjection that is added to a statement that has the effect of questioning something about it.

AStr.Run: So, you are going, <hmm?>

Use this section for verbal auxiliaries, affixes, adverbs, and particles that indicate epistemic moods. Epistemic moods have the whole proposition in their scope and indicate the degree of commitment of the speaker to the truth or future truth of the proposition. They may be combined with any of the tenses, either in the same morpheme or in combinations of morphemes. The following definitions are taken from Bybee, Joan, Revere Perkins, and William Pagliuca. 1994. The evolution of grammar. Chicago and London: University of Chicago Press.

Question.AUni: (1) possibility: the speaker is indicating that the situation described in the proposition is possibly true. Some markers with this meaning also indicate future time: 'He may arrive late because of the weather; It may snow again tomorrow; She could have already taken it'.

(1) مكانيّة: يُشير المتكلّم إلى أنّ الوضعيّة الموصوفة في الجملة يمكن أن تكون صحيحة. كما أنه توجد بعض الكلمات الدلالية مع هذا المعنى وتدلّ كذلك على وقت المستقبل. ''قد يصل متأخّرا نتيجة الحالة الجويّة''. مثال: ''قد تُمطرُ من جديد في الغد." .''قد تكون قد تحصّلت عليه''.

ExampleWords.AUni: may, could,

Question.AUni: (2) probability: the speaker is indicating that the situation described in the proposition is probably true. Some marker with this meaning also indicate future time. This is sometimes called the "Dubitative" in grammars: 'Paula should be home by now'.

(2) حتمال:يُشير المتكلّم إلى أنّ الوضعيّة الموصوفة في الجملة ربّما تكون صحيحة، و توجد بعض الكلمات الدلالية التي تحمل كذلك هذا المعنى لتدلّ على وقت المستقبل. هذا ما يسمّى أحيانا ''بالشكّيّة'' في قواعد اللّغة: ''باولا لابدّ أن تكون في المنزل الآن''.

ExampleWords.AUni: should,

Question.AUni: (3) inferred certainty: the speaker infers from evidence that the proposition is true: 'They must have killed a bear here (I can see blood on the snow)'.

(3) ليقينيّة الإستنتاجيّة: يستنتج المتكلّم من خلال البرهان بأنّ الجملة صحيحة.''لابدّ أنهم قد قتلوا دبّا هنا.''(يُمكنني أن أرى دما على الثّلج.") \qun (4) ليقينيّة: المتكلّم يُؤكّد على أنّ الجملة صحيحة.

ExampleWords.AUni: must have,

Question.AUni: (4) certainty: the speaker is emphasizing that the proposition is true.
(4) دم اليقينيّة: المتكلّم يؤكّد بأنّه لا يعرف بأنّ الجملة صحيحة.

ExampleWords.AUni: certainly,

Question.AUni: (5) uncertainty: the speaker is emphasizing that s/he doesn't know that the proposition is true.
(5) لصيغة الدّلاليّة: الحالة في الجملة الأساسية تكون في الأسئلة. الاختلافات تكون مع صيغة الشّرط وصيغة الأمر.

ExampleWords.AUni: might,

Question.AUni: (6) indicative: main clause mood that also appears in questions. Contrasts with subjunctive, conditional, and imperative.

ExampleWords.AUni: [none in English]

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words that a speaker uses to indicate that he thinks something is certainly true or is certain to happen.

Question.AUni: (1) What words indicate that something is certainly true?
(1) ما هي الكلمات التي تُبرز بأنّ شيئا ما صحيح بصفة مؤكّدة؟

ExampleWords.AUni: certainly, absolutely, definitely, there is no doubt, undoubtedly, without a doubt, without doubt, without a shadow of a doubt, unquestionably, be beyond dispute, there's no denying, there are no two ways about it, there is no question

Question.AUni: (2) What words indicate that something will certainly happen?
(2) ما هي الكلمات التي تعني بأنّ شيئا ما سوف يحدث بشكل مؤكّد؟

ExampleWords.AUni: certainly, definitely, be bound to, be sure to, be certain to, be assured of, be only a matter of time, be just a matter of time, cut and dried, you can bet your life, you can bet your bottom dollar, be a certainty, be a foregone conclusion, for sure

Question.AUni: (3) What words indicate that something will certainly succeed?
